text.p: "Liar Liar" ruled the box office for the third consecutive weekend, and became the first new release of 1997 to break the $100 million mark, according to studio estimates released Sunday.

The Jim Carrey comedy, in which the rubber-faced comic plays a lawyer who must tell the truth for one day, earned about $18.5 million during the Friday to Sunday period, easing just 27 percent from the previous weekend.

Its per-screen average of $6,421 was the second highest in the top 10, and its 17-day total stands at $100.9 million. The only other film to break $100 million this year was the "Star Wars" reissue, which has earned more than $136 million.
"Liar Liar" is released by Universal Pictures, a unit of Seagram Co. Ltd..

The top 10 contained four new releases, of which just one -- "The Saint" in second place -- performed strongly. The others were "That Old Feeling" in fourth, "Double Team" in fifth and "Inventing the Abbotts" in 10th.

However, "Chasing Amy," a boy-meets-lesbian comedy from the writer/director of "Clerks," Kevin Smith, played strongly in exclusive release. The movie earned $57,112 from three screens, for an average of $19,037. It is released by Miramax Films, a unit of Walt Disney Co.

Paramount Pictures' "The Saint," starring Val Kilmer and Elisabeth Shue, earned $16.2 million for an average of $7,000. The movie, based liberally on late novelist Leslie Charteris' books about an enigmatic thief, underwhelmed critics. According to a Variety poll of reviewers in New York, Los Angeles, Chicago and Washington DC, six liked it, 13 did not and 16 were mixed. Entertainment Weekly gave it an "F."
Paramount is a unit of Viacom Inc..

A long way back in third was "The Devil's Own," the Harrison Ford/Brad Pitt thriller, which slipped one notch in its second weekend with $7.4 million. The Columbia Pictures movie, which cost about $90 million to make, fell a hefty 48 percent, and averaged $2,955. Its gross to date is $30 million. Columbia is a unit of Sony Corp..

"That Old Feeling," a Universal romantic comedy starring Bette Midler and Dennis Farina, opened in fourth with $5.2 million for an average of $3,302. "Double Team," a Columbia action movie starring Jean-Claude Van Damme and Dennis Rodman, was close behind with $5.0 million and a non-muscular average of $2,270.

The biggest percentage drop in the top 10 belonged to "Selena," the biopic about the late Tejano singing star. In its third weekend, the Warner Bros. movie fell five places to eighth with $2.7 million. This represents a 56 percent tumble. The movie's gross to date is $27 million. While critics liked it, the Time Warner Inc. -owned studio lamented that it did not display much crossover to non-Latino audiences.

The last of the new releases in the top 10, "Inventing the Abbotts," a period romantic drama with an ensemble cast featuring Liv Tyler and real-life boyfriend Joaquin Phoenix, earned $2.4 million in 10th for an average of $2,676. The movie is released by 20th Century Fox, a unit of News Corp..
